summary: fulminant hepatitis (FH) is a serious life-threatening disease characterized by massive hepatocyte necrosis, severe liver damage, and high mortality. however, accumulating evidence suggests that, regardless of the pathogenesis of FH, the host's inflammatory responses contribute to liver microcirculatory disorders and injuries. clara cell 10 kDa protein (CC10), also considered to be uteroglobin, is one of members of secretoglobin superfamily. CC10 has immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory effects. reduced levels of CC10 are associated with allergic airway diseases. human monocyte cell line THP-1 was purchased from the cell Institute of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (Shanghai, China) human umbilical Vein Endothelial Cells (HUVECs) were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium. peritoneal exudative macrophages were harvested and lysed for real-time PCR and western blotting analysis. apoptosis was detected by the terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase dUTP nick end labeling method with a TUNEL apoptosis detection kit (Roche, Switzerland) cells were washed with PBS and incubated in the dark with goat anti-mouse IgG antibody (1:100, Abnova,) at 4°C for 40 min. cells were then washed with PBS and resuspended in 300 L PBS. immunohistochemistry of liver tissues was performed using SP-9001 SPlink Detection Kits. western blotting Liver tissue and cells were homogenized in RIPA lysis buffer with phenyl methane sulfonyl fluoride (PMSF) protease inhibitor. protein lysates were separated by SDS-PAGE, and western blotting was performed using a monoclonal mouse anti-human/mouse Fgl2 (1:750, Abnova, USA), and a monoclonal rabbit anti- human/mouse mFgl2 forward, 5′-GCC AAA TGT GAG TCC CTG GAA-3′; mFgl2 reverse, 5′-TTC CAC CCA AGA GCA CGT TTA AG-3′; hFgl2 forward, 5′-ACA GTT CAG GCT GGT-3′; hFgl2 forward, 5′-GGC TTA AAG TTG GGT-3′; HBP1 forward, 5′-TGA g pcDNA3.1-hCC10 was mixed gently with lipofectamine 2,000. after incubation, the solution was added to CHO cells and incubated at 37°C in 5% CO2. at 48 h after transfection, cells were collected for real-time PCR and western blot analysis. CHO cells were transfected with pcDNA3.1-hCC10 and pcDNA3.1-hFgl2 for 48 h. western blotting was performed using both rat anti-human uteroglobin/SCGB1A1 Antibody (1:750, R&D, USA) and mouse anti-human Fgl2 antibody (1:500, Abnova). microarray microarray analysis was used to screen changes in genome-wide gene expression patterns in THP-1 cells with or without CC10 protein. changes in over 47,000 human gene expression patterns were assessed using Affymetrix gene microarrays. human umbilical Vein Endothelial Cells (HUVECs) and CHO cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium. THP-1 cells were maintained in RPMI 1,640 containing 10% heat inactivated fetal bovine serum (FBS), 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 mg/mL streptomycin. 5 m sections were deparaffinized, dehydrated through an alcohol series and incubated with proteinase K for 30 min at 37°C. after stopping the proteinase K digestion reaction with PBS, the samples were incubated with terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase end-labeling cocktail. each section was supplemented with reagent (converter-POD) to cover the tissues and incubated for 2 h at 37° immunohistochemistry of liver tissues was performed using SP-9001 SPlink Detection Kits (Biotin-Streptavidin HRP Detection Systems) the expression of Fgl2, fibrinogen, Fas and TNF-receptor 1 in mouse liver tissues was detected with polyclonal rabbit anti-mouse Fgl2 antibody (1:100, Proteintech, USA) real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR) Liver tissues were collected from MHV-3-infected BALB/cJ mice at 72 h. total RNA was extracted using Trizol Reagent (Invitrogen, USA) and then reverse transcribed into cDNA by using ReverTra Ace qPCR RT kit (TOYOBO, Japan) mRNA levels were normalized with reference to the house keeping gene GAPDH. cells were treated with 100 ng/ml phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA) for 48 h to induce differentiation toward adherent macrophage-like cells. the CC10 group was supplemented with CC10 protein (150 ng/ml) after 2 h of stimulation, IFN- (10 ng/ml) was added to these cells. human umbilical Vein Endothelial Cells (HUVECs) were cultured in six-well plates with DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS until 70–80% confluence. 50 pmol HBP1-siRNA was mixed with 125 l serum-free DMEM. at 48 h after transfection, cells were collected for real-time PCR and western blot analysis. the proteins were immunoprecipitated by mouse anti-human Fgl2 antibody (1:500, Abnova) western blotting was performed using both rat anti-human uteroglobin/SCGB1A1 Antibody (1:750, R&D, USA) and mouse anti-human Fgl2 antibody (1:500, Abnova). CC10 improved survival and reduced liver injury in mice. survival rate of CC10 and saline groups was observed for 10 days. CC10 protein (2 g) or saline were injected into mice by tail vein. mice then received 100 PFU of MHV-3 intraperitoneally 24 h later. survival rate was observed for 10 days (n = 24/group) serum ALT and AST levels in the saline group mice reached a peak 72 h after MHV-3 infection. results showed that serum ALT and AST levels in the saline group reached a peak 72 h after MHV-3 infection. CC10 protein has a role in protection against MHV-3-induced liver injury in mice. expression of fgl2 and fibrinogen was reduced in CC10-treated mice after MHV-3 infection. expression of fgl2 in the liver of mice was reduced 72 h after MHV-3 infection and treatment with CC10 protein. CC10 protein inhibited Fgl2 expression and decreased fibrin deposition in mice. CC10 treatment showed a 10.1% decrease in THP-1 cells compared to that in control after stimulation with 10 ng/mL IFN- for 12 h. the strongest inhibitory effect on Fgl2 expression was noted at 12 h. CC10 protein reduced expression of Fgl2 in macrophages. CC10 protein reduced expression of Fgl2 in macrophages. CC10 protein incubated for 12 h had the strongest inhibitory effect on Fgl2 expression among these periods. CC10 reduced the expression of Fgl2 in THP-1 cells. CC10 protein decreases MHV-3-induced Fgl2 production in macrophages. compared to levels in the controls, MHV-3-infected macrophages exhibited a significant increase in Fgl2 production. CC10 protein decreases MHV-3-induced Fgl2 expression in peritoneal exudates macrophages. the experimental group was treated with CC10 protein for microarray detection of differentially expressed genes. the most obviously downregulated genes were UBE2W, HECTD1, MIR612, ATRX, SOX4, HBP1 and Fgl2. qPCR analysis identified HBP1 as a down-regulated gene involved in the pathological processes of the regulation of CC10. 0.05 for the HBP1-siRNA group compared with the control siRNA group. effects of HBP1-siRNA on HBP1 protein by western blot. CC10 protein inhibits the expression of Fgl2 via HBP1. compared to the expression in the blank control and control siRNA group, the expression of Fgl2 increased after stimulation with CC10 protein. in the CC10 group 24 mice were alive on day 3 after infection, 4 mice alive on day 4 and 3 of 24 (12.5%) mice recovered from fulminant viral hepatitis. in saline treated group, there were 5 mice alive on day 3, 1 mice alive on day 4 after infection, and no mice survived to day 5. CC10 protein increased survival rate and reduced liver damage in mice. cJ mice were harvested 72 h after MHV-3 infection. serum ALT and AST levels in the saline group reached peak 72 h. CC10 protein has a role in protection against MHV-3-induced liver injury. levels of TNF- and IL-1 in liver tissues were markedly reduced. CC10 treatment decreased expression of TNF- and IL-1. hepatocyte apoptosis was significantly reduced in the CC10 group. CC10 inhibited Fgl2 expression and decreased fibrin deposition in mice. CC10 treatment reduced liver injury after viral infection by inhibiting Fgl2 expression. CC10 treatment showed a 10.1% decrease in THP-1 cells compared to that in control after stimulation with 10 ng/mL IFN- for 12 h. CC10 protein inhibited Fgl2 expression between doses of 0 ng/mL and 300 ng/mL. the strongest inhibitory effect on Fgl2 expression was noted at 12 h. the CC10 group was supplemented with CC10 protein (150 ng/mL) after 2 h of stimulation, IFN- (10 ng/ml) was added to the cells. CC10 protein incubated for 12 h had the strongest inhibitory effect on Fgl2 expression among these periods. CC10 reduced expression of Fgl2 in THP-1 cells. gene expression of hFgl2 assessed by qPCR. all results were representative of three independent experiments. PEMs were lysed and prepared for western blotting with a polyclonal anti-Fgl2 antibody. data are shown as means and standard error (n = 6/group) all results were representative of three independent experiments. the expression of HBP1 was downregulated after the addition of CC10 protein to the macrophages induced by PMA. CC10 inhibited the expression of HBP1. CC10 Protein Inhibits Fgl2 Expression via HBP1 HBP1-SiRNA was used to transfect HUVECs. IFN- was added to the HUVECs after stimulation with CC10 protein (150 ng/ml) after 2 h. CC10 protein inhibits the expression of Fgl2 via HBP1. CC10 protein was injected into a mouse model established by MHV-3 infection. MHV-3-induced liver injury in CC10-treated mice occurred rarely. previous studies suggested fgl2 played a vital role in this process. CC10 treatment significantly reduced the production of Fgl2 in the infected liver and serum. lower mortality of CC10-treated mice after MHV-3 infection is due to lower levels of Fgl2 and decreased fibrinogen deposition. immunoprecipitation of protein extracts from pcDNA 3.1-CC10 and pcDNA3.1-hFgl2 co-transfected CHO cells with anti-Fgl2 or anti-CC10 antibodies. western blotting with Fgl2 and CC10 antibodies indicated that CC10 did not co-immunoprecipitate with Fgl2. results showed that CC10 has no direct interaction with Fgl2. the potential target of CC10 on other immune cells cannot be excluded. DNA microarray analysis is one of the most powerful approaches for the potential identification of unexpected genes involved in pathogenic processes. conflict of interest Statement The authors declare that the research was conducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could be construed as a potential conflict of interest. Supplementary material The Supplementary Material for this article can be found online at: https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fimmu.2018.02935/full#supplementary-material Supplementary Figure S1 Fgl2 deficiency attenuates MHV-3-induced hepati changes in over 47,000 human gene expression patterns were assessed using Affymetrix gene microarrays (Human Genome U133 Plus 2.0) three replicates were used for microarrays analysis.
